case_vignette: A 65-year-old African American man presents to dermatology clinic for multiple non-painful, non-itchy brown spots on the face. He notes they started developing when he was 42 years old, and they have increased in number and size. Sometimes he tries to remove them with a needle, but they will bleed.   Physical exam reveals multiple dark, flat topped ovoid papules, and few pedunculated brown-black papules on the bilateral zygomatic cheeks.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have multiple non-painful, non-itchy brown spots on my face that have been increasing in number and size over the years.
Have you had any skin changes like this elsewhere on your body, or is it just on your face?
It's just on my face.
How old are you and what is your gender?
I am a 65-year-old man.
Do you have any history of excessive sun exposure or use of tanning beds?
No, I do not have a history of excessive sun exposure or use of tanning beds.
Do these brown spots tend to darken when exposed to sunlight?
I haven't noticed any change in the color of the brown spots when they are exposed to sunlight.
Do you have a personal or family history of skin cancer?
No, I do not have a personal or family history of skin cancer.
Final Diagnosis: Seborrheic keratoses
